Any 2008 | Solbes vs. Pizarro: quan el PSOE es reia de la crisi econòmica

03 Nov 2019, 22:42

¿Quan va començar l’última crisi econòmica? ¿A partir de quin moment exacte es podia preveure el que arribaria a passar? ¿El detonant va ser la caiguda de Lehman Brothers el 15 de setembre del 2008? El cert és que els agents econòmics feia temps que advertien del refredament de l’economia, i fins i tot un organisme tan criticat per la falta de previsió com el Fons Monetari Internacional (FMI) alertava el 2007 que la caiguda dels preus de l’habitatge i del crèdit afectaria molt Espanya. Durant aquell any l’atur ja havia començat a pujar (del 8% al 10%), i les previsions de creixement de l’economia espanyola s’havien revisat a la baixa per a l’any següent.
Res de tot això semblava preocupar el ministre d’Economia i número 2 del PSOE a les eleccions generals del 2008, Pedro Solbes, que va acceptar debatre -en un format inèdit- amb el candidat popular a rellevar-lo en el càrrec, Manuel Pizarro. L’estratègia de l’aspirant va ser en tot moment acusar els socialistes de ser els culpables de la crisi en què, deia, estava a punt d’entrar l’estat espanyol. “Som subcampions europeus en inflació, un dels països amb més endeutament familiar i campions en atur”, va denunciar Pizarro.
“Tinc la sensació que estan convocant la crisi. ¿A vostè, com a coneixedor del món financer, li sembla raonable fer afirmacions com aquestes?”, li va respondre Solbes, que no parava de riure davant les acusacions del seu contrincant. “Ells parlen de crisi i de recessió, i és lluny de la realitat”, va concloure en el minut final el ministre. “Digui als ciutadans que tot està bé. Vostès no han previst el que venia i, si ho han vist, no han fet res per evitar-ho”, li va retreure Pizarro.
Aquell debat a Antena 3 el van veure 4,7 milions de persones, un 24,4% de quota de pantalla. Un any després, la taxa d’atur ja s’enfilava fins al 17% i el 2013 va arribar a vorejar el 27%. Aquell any, Solbes, ja retirat, va assumir que s’havia equivocat: “He rellegit aquell debat i, a posteriori, crec que Pizarro té raó”. Aquelles eleccions les va guanyar el PSOE.
text:
Year 2008 | Solbes vs. Pizarro: when the PSOE laughed at the economic crisis

03 Nov 2019, 22:42

When did the last economic crisis begin? From what precise moment could one predict what would happen? Was the trigger for the fall of Lehman Brothers on September 15, 2008? The truth is that economic agents have long warned of the cooling of the economy, and even a body so criticized by the lack of forecasts as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned in 2007 that the fall in oil prices, Housing and credit would greatly affect Spain. During that year, unemployment had begun to rise (from 8% to 10%), and the growth forecasts of the Spanish economy had been revised downwards for the following year.
Nothing of this seemed to worry the Economy Minister and number 2 of the PSOE in the general elections of 2008, Pedro Solbes, who agreed to debate - in an unpublished format - with the popular candidate to take him into office, Manuel Pizarro . The candidate's strategy was always accusing the Socialists of being guilty of the crisis in which, he said, he was about to enter Spain. "We are European runners-up in inflation, one of the countries with the most family indebtedness and unemployed champions," Pizarro said.
"I have the feeling that they are summoning the crisis. Do you, as a connoisseur of the financial world, find it reasonable to make statements such as these? "Solbes replied, that he did not stop laughing at the accusations of his opponent. "They talk about crisis and recession, and it's far from reality," the minister concluded in the final minute. "Tell the citizens that everything is fine. You have not foreseen what came and, if you have seen it, you have done nothing to avoid it, "Pizarro pleaded.
That debate on Antena 3 was viewed by 4.7 million people, a 24.4% share screen. A year later, the unemployment rate went up to 17% and in 2013 it reached 27%. That year, Solbes, already retired, assumed that he had mistaken: "I have read that debate and, after all, I think that Pizarro is right." Those elections won the PSOE.
